qas.question: How many anginas must a person report to have a STEMI?
ST elevation can develop into what?
The ECG must show less than how many mV for a male to be considered a STEMI?
What has recently been added as a qualification for a STEMI?
Which two named leads only have to be above 1 mm to be counted?

context: For a person to qualify as having a STEMI, in addition to reported angina, the ECG must show new ST elevation in <b0_0>two or more<b0_0/> adjacent ECG leads. This must be greater than 2 mm (<b2_0>0.2 mV<b2_0/>) for males and greater than 1.5 mm (0.15 mV) in females if in leads <b4_0>V2 and V3<b4_0/> or greater than 1 mm (0.1 mV) if it is in other ECG leads. <b3_0>A left bundle branch block<b3_0/> that is believed to be new used to be considered the same as ST elevation; however, this is no longer the case. In early STEMIs there may just be peaked <b1_0>T waves<b1_0/> with ST elevation developing later.
